org.orgName: Circuit Court of the United States, Ninth Judicial Circuit, District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES/, NINTH JUDICIAL CIRCUIT.
In the Matter of the application of George Webster,
To the Hon. C. H. Hanford, Judge of the Circuit Court of the United States, Ninth Judicial Circuit, District of Washington, Northern Division.
The petition of George Webster respectfully shows to your Honor:

First- That the said petitioner is now a prisoner imprisoned and confined in the County Jail at Spokane, Spokane County, State of Washington, in the custody of Robert D. Speck, Sheriff of Spokane County, State of Washington.

Second- That the cause or pretense of the restraint of the said petitioner according to the best of his knowledge and belief is, that on the 13th day of May, 1897, John A. Pierce as proecuting attorney in and for the County of Spokane, State of Washington, made and filed with the Clerk of the Superior Court of the State of Washington, in and for Spokane County, an information, charging the above named petitioner with the crime of murder in the first de- gree, which said information is in writing in words and figures as follows, to-wit:
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON
IN AND FOR THE COUNTY OF SPOKANE.
Information for Murder in the First Degree.

Whereas the hereinafter specified public offense has been com- mitted by the said defendant George Webster, and whereas the said defendant George Webster is not under indictment therefor; and whereas the said defendant is in custody charged with having committed the said public offense; and whereas the said court is in session, and no Grand Jury of, in or for said County is in session; now, there- fore, John A. Pierce, Prosecuting attorney in and for the County of Spokane, and State of Washington, and in the name and by the au- thority of the State of Washington, by this Information informs the said court and gives the said court to understand, know and be informed that the said defendant George Webster is hereby charg- ed with a public offense, to-wit; the crime of murder in the first degree, committed as follows, to-wit; that on the sixth day of May, A. D. 1897, and within three years before the filing of this In- formation, at the County of Spokane and State of Washington, the said defendant George Webster, then and there in the said County and State being, then and there unlawfully, felioniously and pur- posely, and of his deliberate and premeditated malice, killed Lise C. Aspland, by then and there purposely, and of his deliberate and premeditated malice, shooting and mortally wounding the said Lise C. Appland with a gun, commonly called a revolver, which he, the said George Webster, then and there held in his hand, contrary to the Statutes- in such case made and provided and against the peace and dignity of the State of Washington.
JOHN A. PIERCE. Prosecuting attorney and Informant.

Harris Baldwin, being first duly sworn, upon his oath deposes and says; that he is the duly appointed, qualified and act- ting deputy prosecuting attorney in and for the County of Spo- kane, State of Washington, and that all and singluar the several statements, allegations, matters and things set out in the above and foregoing information are true.
Sworn to and subscribed before me this 13th day of May, A. D. 1897. E. T. WHITE
Notary Public for the State of Washington, residing at Spokane Washington.
Names of Witnesses known to the prosecuting attorney at the time of filing this information:
Frances A. Pomeroy Andrew Aspland Ella May Aspland Abel Brown M. A. Wilkinson
John H. Aspland E. T. White Jennie Aspland W. D. Switzer Franz Magnus
John M. Sempee Mary Sawyer Wm. C. Spence J. E. Corbett John Eldridge

Second-a- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in said cause in said Superior Court that the said cause coming on regularly for trial, one N. C. Hair, was called as a juror in said cause upon being examined touching his qualifications to act as a jurir in said cause, answered that he was at said time the client of John A. Pierce who was then the prosecuting attorney for Spokane County, Washington, and who was then representing the State of Washington in the said cause, and thereupon the said George Webster by his attorneys, challenged the said juror N. C. Hair, for implied bias on the ground that the relation of attorney and client at said time existed between the sad juror and the said prosecut- ion attorney/ and that the said juror N. C. Hair was, under the pro- visions of Sec. 345 of Vol. 2 of Hills Code of the State of Washing- ton, which is as follows; "Standing in the relation of guardi- an and ward, attorney and client, master and servant, or landlord and tenant, to the adverse party; or being a member of the family of, or a partner in business with, or in the employment for wages of the adverse party etc., "disqualified and incompetent to

Second B- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in said cause in said Superior Court, that the said cause coming on regularly for rial one John E. Valentine was called as a juror to answer questions touching his qualifications to act as a juror in said cause, and upon examination of the said juror John E. Val- entine, touching his qualifications, he, the said huror testified as follows;

Q From what you read did you form an opinion as to the guilt of innocence of the defendant? A Well, as is natural when a person reads anything of that kind he would have an opinion. Q Have you that opinion now? A Well, somewhat. Q Is that such an opinion as would require evidence to remove or change? A Some. Yes sir. Q Would it require strong evidence to change your opinion? A Fairly good. Q In that such an opinion as would require the evidence of at least one witness to change? A Yes sir. Q Is that opinion that you have now, a fixed and decided opinion from what you have reas? A no. Q Assuming what you have read to be true have you, then a fixed and decided opinion? A Yes sir. If it was true, Q Welll, at any rate you now entertain an opinion that would re- quire strong evidence to remove? A Well, it would require some evidence, yes sir. Not particularly strong evidence; it would require some evidence. Q It would require some evidence of at least one witness? A Yes sir. Q To change your present opinion? A Yes sir.

That thereupon the said petitioner by his said attorneys chal- lenged the said juror John E. Valentine, for cause on the ground of actual bias, which said challenge of the said petitioner wasthen and there denied by the said Superior Court, to which the said pe- titioner duly excepted and an exception was allowed. And petitioner alleged, that under the laws of the State of Washington in force at the time of the trial of this cause, the said petitioner was en- titled to exercise twelve peremptory challenges; and petitioner further alleges, that upon the trial of said cause upon the said in- foormation he, the said petitioner did exercse eleven peremptory challenges, and did excuse eleven jurors peremptorily.

Third- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in said cause in the said Superior Court, of the State of Washington, in and for the County of Spokane, that on the 14th day of May, A. D. 1897, the attorneys for the said petitioner made and filed with the clerk of the said Superior Court a motion to quash and set aside the said information, which said motion is in writing in words and figures as follows, to-wit:
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THESTATE OF WASHINGTON FOR SPOKANE COUNTY
Comes now the above named defendant by his attorneys Del Cary Smith, and moves the court to quash and set aside the in- formation filed herein and for grounds of said motion alleges;
1- That the information filed herein is not verified as re- quired by law.
2- That it does not appear from said information or from any of the record or proceedings in this cause, that the State of Wash- ington is entitled to prosecute herein by information.
3- That as appears from the information in this cause, this court has no jurisdiction of the person of the defendant, or of the subject matter of this action.
4- That said information is not direct or certain as regards either the party charged, the crime charged, or the particular cir- cumstances of the crime charged.
5- That said information charges more than one crime and in more than one form.
6- That the said act or omission charged as the crime in said information is not clearly and distinctly setforth in ordinary and concise language as required by law.

7- That the act or omission charged as the crime in said in- formation is not stated with such a degree of certainty as to en- able the court to pronounce judgment upon a conviction according to the rights of the case.
8- That said information does not inform the said defendant of the nature and cause of the accusation against him.

9- Tht it has never been judicially or otherwise established, that there was or is probable cause to believe that the said defend- ant ever committed the crime attempted to be alleged in the said information, and as appears from the records in this cause, on file with the clerk of this court, the said information was filed against the said defendant without any probable cause first having been established and shown.

10 That at a pretended preliminary examination held in this cause, on the 12th day of May 1897, before Hon. C. F. Backus, a Justice of the Peace, the said defendant over the objections of his counsel was denied the rights and protection guaranteed to him by the laws and Constitution of the State of Washington, and that said Justice, over the objections of defendant admitted all manner of sham, irrelevant, incompetent, immaterial and hearsay testimony against him.
11- That said information does not substantially comply with the requirements of the criminal code of the State of Washington.
This motion is based upon the files and records herein.
Del Cary Smith, Attorney for defendant.
No. 771 Filed May 14th, 1897, at 9:15 o'clock, A. M.

Fourth- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in t he said Superior Court, that the said motion of the said peti- tioner to quash and set aside the said information came on regular- ly for hearing before the Judge of the said Superior Court and upon the argument thereof, the same was overruled, to which the said petitioner then and there duly excepted, and an exception was allowed by the said Superior Court.

Fifth- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in said cause in the said Superior Court, that the at- torneys for the said petitioner on the 25th day of May, A. D. 1897, made and filed with the Clerk of the said Superior Court a demurrer to the said information which said demurrer is in writing, in words and figures as follows, to-wit:
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON FOR SPOKANE COUNTY
That said information does not substantially conform to the requirements of the criminal code of the State of Washington.
2- That the facts charged in said information do not consti- tute a crime or public offense.
3- That as appears from the record in this court in this cause, this court has no jurisdiction of the person of the defendant or the subject matter of the action.
4- That said information does not inform the defendant of the nature and cause of the accusation against him.
5- That it does not appear from said information or from any of the records or proceedings in this cause, that the State of Wash- ington is entitled to prosecure theis cause by information.
6- that as appears from all the records in this cause the in- formation herein is void and the defendant is now deprived of his liberty without due process of law.
7- That the said information is not direct and certain as re- gards either the party charged, the crime charged, or the particular circumstances of the crime charged.
8- That the act or omission charged as the crime in said infor- mation is not clearly and distinctly setforth in ordinary and con- cise language as required by law.

9- That the act or omission charged as the crime in said infor mation is not stated with such a degree of certainty as to enable the court to pronounce judgment upon a conviction according to the rights of the case.
10- That said information charges more than one crime and in more than one form.

11- That it has never been judicially or otherwise established that there was or is probable cause to believe that the said defend- ant ever committed the crime attempted to be alleged in the said information, and as appears from the records in this cause, on file with the clerk, the said information was filed against the said de- fendant without any probable cause first having been established and shown.
Del Cary Smith Attorney for the defendant.

Sixth- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in said cause in said Superior Court, that the said cause coming on regularly to be heard upon the said demurrer, and the said Superior Court having heard argument thereon, overruled the same to which order overmling the same the said petitioner then and there duly excepted, and the said exception was allowed by the said Superior Court.

Seventh- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in said cause in the said Superior Court, the jury which was im anell- ed and sworn to try the said petitioner upon the said charge in the said information, did, on the 25th day of September, A. D. 1897, render and reutrn unto the said Superior Court their verdict in said cause, which is in writing, in words and figures asfollows to-wit;
We, the jury of the case of the State of Washigton, Plaintiff
find the defendent George Webster, GUILTY as charged in the infor- mation.

Eighth- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in said cause in said Superior Court, that on the 15th day of Nov- ember, A. D. 1897, the attorneys for the said petitioner made and filed with the Clerk of the said Superiorb Court, a moti on in ar- rest of judgement which said motion in arrest of judgment is in writ- ing, in words and figures as follows, to-wit;
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON, IN AND FOR THE COUNTY OF SPOKANE.

Comes now the above named defendant by his attorney's Del Cary Smith and James E. Fenton, and moves the court that judgment upon the verdict herein be arrested and stayed, and that the information herein be dismissed, and that the defendant be dischaged from cus- today and for grounds of said motion the defendant alleges;
1- That the facts as stated in the information herein does not constitute a crime or misdemeanor.
2- That the prosecuting attorney had no authority to file the information in this cause.
3- That the information herein is not verified as required by law.
4- That the above entitled court had no jurisdiction of the said defendant or of the charge in the information herein.
5- That the verdict rendered herein does not conform to the information herein.
6- That there is a variance between the evidence in this cause and the allegations in the information herein.

7- That the statutes under which the information herein was filed, and under whichthe said defendant was tried and convicted, is unconstitutional and void, and in violation of the 5th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States.
8-That the said information herein charges more than one crime and in more than one form.
9- That the verdict rendered in said cause is indefinite and uncertain and wholly insufficient to support a judgment thereon.
10- That the records and proceedings in this cause does not sufficiently show that the defendant entered any plea to the infor- mation filed herein.
11- That the records and proceedings in this cause do not show that the said defendant was present in court, during the material steps taken in the trial of said cause.
This motion is based upon all records, proceedings and filed in the above entitled cause.
Del Cary Smith and James E. Fenton, Attorneys for defendant.

Ninth- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in said cause, that the said cause coming on regilarly to be heard upon the said motion in arrest of judgment, and the same being argued te the said Superior Courtoverruled the same, towhich ruling the said petitioner then and there excepted and an exception was then and there allowed by the said Superior Court.

Tenth- That thereafter such proceedings were had an take n in said cause, in said Superi or Court, that on the 16th day of Novem- b er, A.D.1897, the Hon. Leander H. Prather as Judge of the said Superior Court rendered and made his judgement and sentence in said cause, which said judgment and sentence is i n writing in words and figures as follows, to-wit;
In the Superior Court of the State of Washington
in and for the County of Spokane.

Whereas at a day of the said Superior Court, before the Hon. Leander H. Prather, Judge of said Court, on the 13th day of May, 1897 in open Court, and in due form of law, John A. Pierce, Prosecuting attorney in and for said County, in said State, presented, preferr- ed and caused to be filed, and there was on the said 13th day of May 1897, filed in the said Court, an information against t he said de- fendant, George Webster, charging him, the said defen dant, George Webster, with the crime of Muder in the first degree, in that he, the said defendant, George Webster, in said County and State, on, to- wit, the 6th day of May, 1897, then and there unlawfully, felonious- ly and purposely and of his deliberate and premeditated malice, did kill Lise C. Aspland, by then and there purposely, and of his de- liberare and premeditated malice, shooting and mortally wounding the said Lise C. Aspland, with a gun, commonly called a revolver, ehich he, the said defendant, George Webster, then and there held in his hand; and,

Whereas the said defendant George Webster, thereafter and on t the 13th day of May, 1897, being personally present in open court with his attorneys, James E Fenton and Del Cary Smith/ was duly and personally arraigned upon the said information in open court, and on the 14th day of May, 1897, this said defendant, George Webster bei ng present in person and by his attorneys in open Court, did plead not guilty to the said crime in the said information charged, and

Whereas, thereafter and on to-wit, the 17th day of May, Septem- ber, 1897, in due course of law, a jury of twelve good and lawful men was duly selected, accepted, impanelled and sworn to well and truly try and true deliverance make between the said State of Wash- ington and the prisoner at the bar, to-wit, the said defendant George Webster, whom they, the said jury, then and there had in chargem accordi ng to the evidence, and

Whereas, after hearing the evidence in the said cause, and the arguments for the said State of Washington and the said defendant, George Webster, respectively, and after hearing and receiving the instructions of the said court, the said jury did retire in charge of sworn officers to deliberate on their verdict in said cause, and thereafter and on-to-wit; the 25th day of September, 1897, the said jury did return and render into open court, the said defendaant George Webster, being then and there personally present, in open court, with his said attorneys, the following verdict, to-wit; Case No. 771
VECR D I C T O F G U I L T Y
We, the jury in the case of the State of Washington, Plaintiff vs. George Webster, defendant, find the defendantGeorge webster GUILTY as charged in the information.

And whereas, thereafter and on to-wit; the 27th day of September, 1897, the said defendant George Webster, by his said attorneys, gave a nd filed in said court notice of motion for a new trial and motion for a new trial herein, and on to-wi t, the 8th day of November, 1897, did file in the said Court affidavits in support of said mo- tion for a new trial; and on the 15th day of November, 1897, the said defendant George Webster, being then and there personally pre ent with his said attorneys in open court; and thereafter, and on, to-wit, the 15th day of November, 1897, the said defendant George Webster, with his said attorneys being personally present in open court, the said motion in arrest of judgment was overruled by the said court.

And the said court having on said 15th day of November, 1897, fixed the 16th day of November, 1897, as the day on which the said court would make, render and enter judgment and sentence upon said verdict,-

NOW, on this, the 16th day of November, 1897, the said c court being in session, and the said defendant, George Webster being personally present with his said attorney, Del Cary Smith, in open court, the said court informed the said defendant George Web- ster of the said cerdict of the said jury, and then and there asked the said defendant, George Webster, if hem the said defendant George Webster had any cause to show wh y said court should not pro- nounce, an d make, render and enter judgment and sentence of said court upon said verdict; and there, being no cause shown by or on behalf of the said defendant, George Webster, the court prnounced made, rendered and entered and does hereby make, render and enter, upon the said verduct the following sentence, to-wit;

Upon the verdict of the jury in this cause, finding you, the said defendant, George Webster, guily of murder in the first degree for the killing of Lise C. Aspland, the judgment of this court is that you are guilty of the crime of murder in the first degree, therefore, the judgment and sentence of thi s court is that you, the said defendant George wWebster, be taken hence by the sheriff of said county to the jail of said county, and there safely and secure- ly kept until a time and day certain, to be fixed in the warrant for your execution; and that upon said day, between the hours of six o'clock and ten o'clock in the forenoon of saidm day, so to be so fixed, you be taken from t he saud jail by the said sheriff to a place to be by him selected and provided, within the yard of the jail of said county, in the city of spokane, County of Spokane, State of Washington, and that you then and there by the sheriff be hanged by the neck until you are dead.
Done in open court, this the 16th day of November, 1897.
No. 771 Filed Nov. 16th, 1897 at 3 o'clock, P.M. J. R. Low, Clerk

Eleventh- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in said cause in said Superior Court, that on the 16th day of Nov- ember, A.D.1897, the Hon. Leander H. Prather as judge of the said Superior Court, issued a death warrant upon the said judgment and sentence which said death warrant is in writing in words and figures as follows, to-wit;
In the Superior Court of the State of Washington
in and for t h e County of Spokane.
To C. C. Dempsey, Sheriff of Spokane County, State of Washing- ton, GREETING:

Whereas at a lay of the Superior Court of Spokane County, before the Honorable Leander H. Prather, judge of said Court, begun and held at the City of Spokane, in the said county of Spokane, on the 13th day of May, 1897, in open-court, and in due form of law, John A. Pierce, prosecuting attorney for Spokane County, State of Washington, presented an information against the said defendant George Webster, charging him with the crime of murde in the first degree, in that, he, the said defendant George Webster i n said county and State, onto-wit, the 6th day of May, 1897, then and there unlawfully, feloniously and purposely, and of his deliber- ate and premeditated malice, did kill Lise C. Aspland, by then and there purposely and of his deliberate and pemeditated malice, shooting and mortally wounding the said Lise C. Aspland, with a gun commonly called a revolver, which he, the said George Webster, then and there held in his hand; and,

Whereas this case came on regularly for hearing in the Super- ior Court of the State of Washington in and for the County of Spokane, on the 13th day of May, 1897, the said court beig in sess- ion, and the said defendant being present in person in open court and represented by his attorneys, Messrs James E. Fenton and Del Cary Smith, and the state of Washingto n being represented by John A. Pierce, prosecuting attorney for said Spokane County, and, it ap pearing to the court that said defendant had been duly and regu- larly examined and committed by a magistrate of said county and state, upon the charge of murder in t he first degree, and that an information had been duly presented and filed against him, the said defendant George Webster, in the said Superior Court by John A. Pierce, prosecuti ng attorney as aforesaid, charging him the said defendant, George Webster, with the crime of murder inthe first de- gree, thereupon the said defendant George Webster, in open court was duly arraigned under said information and asked to plead thereto and thereupon the said defendant George Webster pleaded not guilty to the said crime in the said information charged, and

Whereas, thereafter and on to-wit, the 17th day of September, 1897, in due course of law, a jury of twelve good and lawful men, to-wit, C. Thomas Willia, P. Gould, Thomas James, H. W. Doane, J. F. Roadnight, I. Lipschuetz, J. E. Valentine, U. H. Morgan, N. C. Hair, John Q. Van Ness, William Gill and R. J. Frazier, drawn from the body of said Spokane County, were duly selected, accepted, im- panelled and sworn to well and truly try and true deliverance make between the State of Washington and the prisoner at the bar, to-wit the said defendant George Webster, whom they the said jury, t hen and there hadin charge, according to the evidence; and

Whereas, after hearing the evidence in the said cause and the arguments for the said State of Washington and the said defendant George Webster; respectively, and after hearing and receiving the instructions of the said Court, the said jury did retire in charge of sworn officers and to deliberate on their verdict in the said cause; and thereafter, and on, to-wit, the 25th day of September, 1897, the said jury did return and render into open court, the said de- fendant George Webster, being then and there personally present in open court with his s said attorneys, the following verdict, to- wit:
VER D I C T O F G U I L T Y
We, the jury in the case of the STATE OF WASHINGTON, Plaintiff vs. George Webster, Defendant, find the defendant George Webster GUILTY as charged in the Information.

And Whereas, thereafter and on to-wit, the 27th day of Septem- ber, 1897, the said defendant George Webster, by his attorneys, gave and filled in said court notice of motion for a new trial and motion for a new trial herein, and on, to-wit, the 8th day of November, 1897, did file in the said court affidavits in support of sai d motion for a new trial; and on the 15th day of November, 1897 the said defendant, George Webster, being then and there personally present, with his said attorneys in open court; and thereafter, and on, tow-ti the 15th day of November, 1897, the said defendant George Websterm by his said attorneys, filed a motion for arrest of judg- ment herein, and on the 15th day of November, 1897, the said de- fendant George Webster, with his sai d attorneys being personally p resent in open court, the said motion in arrest of judgment was overruled by the said court; and

Whereas, the said court did on said 15th day of November, 1897, fix the 16th day of November, 1897, as the day on which the said court would make, render and enter judgment and sentence upon said verdict, and

Whereas, on the 16th day of November, 1897, the said court be- ing in session, and the said defendant George Webster, being person- ally present with his said attorneys, Del Cary Smith, in open court , the said court informed the said defendant George Webster, had any cause to show why the said court should not prnounce, and make render and enter judgment and sentence of said court upon said verdict; and, there being no cause shown by or on behalf of the said defendant, George Websterm the said court did then and there pronounce, make render and enter, upon the said verdict, the following sentence, to-wit; Upon the verdict of the jury in this cause, finding you, the said defendant George Webster, guilty of muder in the frst degree for the killing of Lise C. Aspland, the judgmet of this court is that you are guilty/of the crime of mur- der in the first degree; therefore, the judgment and sentence of this court is that you, the said defendant George Webster, be taken hence by the sheriff of said county to the jail of said county, and there safely and securely kepy until a day and time certain, to be fixed in the warrant for your execuution; mand that upon said day, between the hours of six o'clocl and ten o'clock in the forenoon of said day, so to be fixed, you be taken from the said jail by the said sheriff to a place to be by him selected and provided withi n the yard of the jail of said county in the city of Spokane, county of Spokane, State of Washington, and that you then and there by the said sheriff be hanged by the neck until you are dead:-

WHEREFORE, it is by the court ordered, and, in the name of the STATE OF WASHINGTON, you, C. C. Dempsey, Sheriff of Spokane County State of Washington, are hereby commanded to take the said defend- ant, George Webster, on the 14th day of February, A.D. 1989, between the hours of six o'clock and ten o'clock un the forenoon of said day, to the said place of execution, in the yard of the jail of said Spokane County, and that you, the said C. C. Dempsey, Sheriff as aforesaid, then and there hang the said defendant, George Webster, by the neck until he is dead; and that you, the said C. C. Dempsey, sher iff as aforesaidm make due execution and return of this warrant and your proceedings thereon as required by law.
GIVEN under my hand and the seal of said court, this 16th day of November, . D. 1897 (SEAL)
Leander H. Prather. Judge of the Superi or Court of the State of Wash., in and for Spokane County.
No. 771 Filed Nov. 16th/1897 at 4:30 o'clock P. M. J.R.Low, Clerk By G. J. Donovan, Deputy. Recorded Journal 41 page 532

Eleven 1/2- That thereafter such proceedings were had in said cause, in the said Superior Court, that the said petitioner George Webster made and filed in the said Superior Court, his pe- tition for a writ of error Coram nobis, whiych said petition for a writ of error coram nobis, is in writing in words and figures as follows, to-wit;
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON, IN AND FOR THE COUNTY OF SPOKANE.
George Webster, Peitioner in error, -vs- The State of Washington, Defendant in error.
In the Matter of the application of George Webster
A Writ of Error Corim Nobis
To the above named plaintiff the State of Washington, defendant and respondant in error herein, and to John A. Pierce, Prosecuting Attorney in and for the County of Spokane, State of Washington.

You, and each of you will take notice that the above named George Webster, petitioner, relator and defedant above named, will on Tuesday, the 4th of January, A. D. 1898, at the hour of nine A. M. of the said day, or as soon thereafter as he can be heard, apply to the Hon. L. H. Prather, on of the judges of the above entitled Court, and the Judge who tried the case No. 771, entitled the State of Washington, Plaintiff, vs. George Webster, defendant, for a Writ of Error Corim Nobis, and upon the hearing of said Writ of Error, the said petitioner, relator and defendant above named, will ask to have the Errors of Facts assigned in his petition herein, and supported by the affidavits filed with his petition, tried and decided by a Jury, to be impannelled by the said Superior Court, and if the Jury shall find in favor of said petitioner, relator and defendant, ask for a judgment and decree of said Court, revoking and recalling the judgment and sentence heretofore made and rendered by said Court, and that upon said hearing the said petitioner will ask for an order of said Court that execution of said sentence be stayed and ar- reated pending the hearig and determination of this matter.
Del Cary Smith Fenton and O'Brien, Attorneys for Petitioner, Relator and defendant above named
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON, IN AND FOR THE COUNTY OF SPOKANE.
George Webster, Peitioner in error, -vs- The State of Washington, Defendant in error.
In the Matter of the application of George Webster
A Writ of Error Corim Nobis
The petitioner, relator and defendant above named comes now, and for this his petition for a Writ of Error Coram Nobis alleges:

1- That on the 13th day of May, A. D. 1899, the Prosecuting Attorney in and for Spkane County, Washington, filed an information in the above entitled court, charging the said petitioner, relator and defendant above named, with the crime of Murder in the first de- gree, alleged to have been committed as follows: That he the said petitioner, relator and defendant above named, on the 6th day of May A. D. 1897, and within three years next before the filing of said information in the County of Spokane, State of Washington, then and there being, did then and there unlawfully, felioniously and purpose- ly and of his deliberate and premeditated malice, kill Lice C. Asp- land with a gun, commonly called a revolver, which he the said Georg3 Webster then and there held in his hand.

2- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken upon the said information. That on the 14th day of September, A. D. 1897, the said cause No. 771 wherein the State of Washington was Plaintiff and George Webster, this petitioner was defendant, was called for trial, the said State of Washington being represented by John A. Pierce Prosecuting Attorney, and the said George Webser the peti- tioner and relator herein being present in person and represented by Del Cary Smith and James E. Fenton, his attorneys, a jury was ther upon called to enter the jury box and after being sworn to answer questions touching their qualifications were examined by Counsel f or the State and the defendant, the petitioner and relator herein, whereupon on the 17th day of September, A. D. 1897, the following jury was impanelled, selected abd sworn to try the said cause to-wit: Wm Gill, C. Thomas, J. T. Roadnight, W. P. Gould, John Valentine, N. C. Hair, U. H. Morgan, Thomas James, Isador Lipschaetz, H. W. Doane, John Q. Van Ness and R. J. Frazier.

That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in said cause, No. 771, entitled the State of Washington, plaintiff -vs- George Webster defendant, that on or about the 25th day of September, cause found and returned to the above entitled Court, their verdict finding the defendant guilty as charged in the information.

3- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in the above entitled cause, that on the 27th fau of September, A. D. 1897, the said George Webster, the petitioner and relator herein filed with the Clerk of the above entitled Court, his Motion to va- cate and set aside the said verdict and for a new trial of said cause

4- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in the above entitled cause, that on the 15th day of November, A. D. 1897, the said Motion for a new trial came on for hearing before the Hon. L. H. Prather, one of the Judges of the above entitled Court, and the Judge who tried said cause, and the said motion being argued by counsel for the State of Washington and for the defendant, and the said Court being advised, ordered, and adjudged that the said motion for a new trial be overruled, to which the said George Webster then and there excepted.

5- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in said cause, No. 771, entitled the State of Washington, plaintiff, -vs- George Webster, defendant that on the 15th day of November, A. D. 1897, the said George Webster, the petitioner and relator herein, filed his motion in the above entitled Court to arrest judgment upon the said verdict.

6- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in said cause, No. 771, entitled the State of Washingyon, plaintiff, -vs- George Webster, defendant, that on the 15th day of November, A. D. 1897, the Hon. L. H. Prather one of the Judges of the above entitled Court, and the Judge who tried said cause, made an order overrul- ing said Motion in arrest of judgmet, to which the said George Web- ster then and there excepted.

7- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in said cause, No. 771, entitled the State of Washingyon, plaintiff, -vs- George Webster, defendant, that on the 16th day of November, A. D. 1897, the Hon. L. H. Prather one of the Judges of the above entitled Court, and the Judge who tried said cause, made and rendered judgment upon the said verdict adjudging the said George Webster the petition- er and relator hearein, to be hanged by the neck until dead.

8- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in the above entitled cause, that on the 16th day of November, A. D. 1899, a warrant was issued out of the above entitled Court, directed to the Sheriff to take the said George Webster the relator and petitioner herein on the 4th day of February, A. D. 1898, between the hours of six o'clock and ten o'clock in the forenoon of said day, to the place of execution in the yard of the jail of said Spokane County, and then and there hang the said George Webster, the petitioner and relator herein, by the neck until he should be dead.
9- And the said George Webster the petitioner and relator here in, further alleges and assigns as an error of fact for which a writ of Coram Nobis should issue herein, that upon the examination of

isador Lipschetz one of the jurors who tried the said George Webster the petitioner and relator herein, touching the qualifications of said juror to sit as a trial juror in said cause, the following ques- tions were propounded to the said Isadoe Lipschuetz, and the said Isador Lipschuetz deposed and testified under oath as follows:

Q What is your name? A I. Lipschuetz. Q Mr. Lipschuetz where do you live? A Here in Spokane Q How long have you lived here, Mr. Lipschuetz? A About eight years. Q Are you a married man? A Yes sir. Q Your family live here? A Yes sir. Q What is your business? A I am a barber. Q Where is your place of business? A 515 Main Street. Q Do you know the defendant, George Webster? A I do not. Q Do you know his attorneys, Mr. Fenton and Mr. Smith? A No. Q Do you know anything about the facts in this case? A No Sir. Q Have you read anything in the paper about it? A I did. Q Did you read what purported to be the report of the shooting immediately after it occurred, in the paper? A I read about it in the papers. Q From the reading of those reports, or from any other reason, did you form or express any opinion as to the guilt or innocence of the defendant. A No sir. Q Have you now any opinion as to his guilt or innocence? A No sir. Q Mr. Lipschuetz, do you understand the meaning of the term circumstantial evidence? A Yes sir. Q What is your notion about that? A My notion about the meaning of the term circumstantial evidence is that circumstances, not witnesses, or the things connecting the defendant with the case. Q Would the trial of a cause be willing to convict the defendant upon purely, solely circumstantial evidence? A If there was no doubt about the guilt I would. Q Taking a chain of circumstances that point to the guilt of a defendant, would you be willing wholly upon circumstantial evidence to convict in a case of murder in the first degree, where you knew that your verdict would mean the hanging of a man? A If there was no doubt or question in my mind that according to the evidence he was guilty. Q Could you remove all doubt from your mind by hearing of circumstantial evidence only? A That would depend on how strong the evidence was, Q If it was strong enough, you think circumstantial evidence alone could remove any doubt from your mind as completely as if you heard witnesses who saw the transaction? A Well, I would certainly give the prisoner the beneifit of the doubt if there was any exisiting. Q You should enter upon the trial of the cause with a doubt in your mind in any case, would you not? Would you not give the prisoner the benefit of the presumption of innocence starting out in the trial? A Yes Sir. Q Then you would start in the trial of any case with a doubt in your mind in favor of the prisioner? A Well, I had not thought of the guilt of the prisoner. Q You mean that you would rely on the presumption of his inn- ocence until you have heard the evidence? A Yes sir, Q Then you hage a doubt in favor of the prisioner in any event in starting out in a trial? A Yes, I suppose so. Q Now, starting out with that doubt, or with that idea of the pre- sumption of the innocence of the defendant until he is proven guity could circumstantial evidence alone remove that doubt or remove the presumption of innocence that would be in your mind? A Yes sir. Q Have you any opinion, Mr. Lipschuetz which would preclude you from rendering a verdict of guilty in any case, where the offence would be punished by penalty of death? A No sir. Q You have no conscientious scruples against hanging? A No. Q What is your nationality? A I was born in Germany Q Do you belong to any secret society here? A None whatever.
The Prosecuting Attorney passed said juror for cause. The said juror, I. Lipschuetz upon examination of Mr. Fenton of counsel for defendant, deposed as follows:

Q Have you read anything about this case? A I have Q When was that? A At the time the shooting ocurred last spring. Q When was that? A Sometime last spring, when it took place. Q Have you talked about this case, State against Webster? A Nothing but comment upon what I read. Q Have you talked with anyone else about the case? A No sir. Q Now from what you have read about the case, and from what you have heard about it, have you formed any opinion as to the guilt or innocence o the defendant? A I never form an opinion on newspaper talk. Q Have you now any opinion as the the guilt or innocence of the de- fendant? A None whatsoever. Q Have you any opinion as to whether or not Mrs. Aspland was kille A Only from what I saw in the papers. I have no opinion about it. Q What is that? A Only what I saw in the papers? Q Have you any such opinion that would require evidence to change? A Evidence to change my opinion? Q Have you now such an opinion as to require evidence to change that opinion? A No sir. Q You say you would convict a person charged with murder in the first degree wholly on circumstantial evidence? A If there was not adooubt as to the evidence as to his being guilty. Q Suppose that the evidence was slight and circumstantial, would you then have any conscientious scruples against convicting? A No sir, I would not. Q What is your business? A I am a barber. Q Where is your place of business? A 515 Main Street. Q Are you acquainted with Mr. Pierce? A Not personally, but I know him when I see him. Q Are you acquianted with Mr. Fitzgerald? A. Only by sight. Q Are you acquainted with Mr. Baldwin? A No sir Q Or Mr. Aspland? A No sir. Q Did you ever sit on a jury before? A I sat in a justice court once. Q Did you ever sit as a juror in this Court before, or any other district or superior court? A No sir. Q If the defendant should go upon the witness stand and testify in his own behalf, cud you give his testimony the same weight and credit as that of ay other witness similarly situated? and surrounded by the same circumstances? A Yes sur. Q Would the fact that he should not go upon the witness stand raise any nference in your mind as to his guilt? A None whatever. Q You think that you could give the defendant the benefit of all resonable doubt? A Yes sir. Q Do you know anything that would prevent you from being a fair and impartial juror? A Not to my knowledge, Q Should the jury in this case, a majority of them, be against your opinion after hearing the evidence, do you think that you could adhere to the opinion you had formed in your own consciousness after hearing the evidence A I certainly could. Q You think that your verdict would be based upon the evidence as you understood it and not upon the understanding of your fellow jurors? A Yes sir. Q You are a marrued man? A. Yes sir.
The defendant passed said juror for cause.

That the foregoing questions were all the questions propounded to the juror, Isador Lipschuetz, and the foregoing answers to said questions were all the testimony and questions of the Juror Isador Lipschuetz upon his examination as said Juror in said cause and said juror gave no other testimony upon his said examination.

Whereas in truth and in fact the said Isador Lipschuetz at the time of his said examination as juror, had not been a resident of the City of Spokane or the State of Washington, for the period of eight years, and in truth and in fact had not been a resident of the State of Washington for the period of one year next before the time that he the said Juror Isador Lipschuetz was being examined touching his qualifications to sit as a Juror in said cause, which he the said Juror Isador Lipschuetz then and there well knew; and in truth and in fact the said Juror Isador Lipschuetz voted at the town of Wallace in voting Precinct No. 2 at the general election held in said Precinct, in the State of Idaho on the 3rd day of November A. D. 1896, and in truth and in fact resided in the State of Idaho until the 1st day of Janurary, A. D. 1897. And the said petitioner, rela- tor and defendant above named alleges; that at the time of the said examination of the said Juror Isador Lipschuetz touching his qualifi- cations to sit as juror in said cause, he the said petitioner, relator and defendant, had no knowledge whatever that the said juror Isador Lipschuetz was not a resident of the State of Washington for the period of one year prior to said time, or that he the said juror was not an elector of the State of Washington or that he the said juror was not an inhabitant of Spokane County, Washington, for the period of one year next preceeding the time when he, the said juror, was drawn and called, and he the said petitioner, relator and defendant herein further alleges; that at the time of the examination of the said juror Isador Lipschuetz, he and his said attorneys were wholly unacquainted with the said Juror Isador Lipschuetz and had no means of knowing at said time how long he had been an inhabitant of Spo- kane County, or how long the said juror has resided in the State of Washington, or whether or not he the said juror was an elector of the State of Washington, but he, the said petitioner, relator and defend- ant herein and his sais attorneys relied wholly upon the truth of the answer of said juror as to the length og his residence i Spo- kane County, Washington, and that he the said petitioner, relator and defendant above further aleges that neither he nor his said attorneys became aware of the fact that the said juror Isador Lipschuetz had not been a resident oand inhabitant of Spokane County, Washington for the periodof one year next preceeding the time that the said jurr was drawn, called and examined and that he the said juror was not an elector of the State of Washington at the said time, and was not competent to act as a juror in said cause, and had no knowledge whatever in relation thereto, until the 18th day of Novem- ber A. D. 1897, at which time one of the attorneys Del Cary Smith for the said petitioner, relator and defendant above named, received a letter from the town of Wallace, State of Idaho, informing him of the fact that the said juror had voted in Wallace Precinct, No. 2 in Shoshone County in the State of Idaho, at the general election held in said Precinct on the 3rd day of November, A. D. 1896, and that he the said juror had not been a resident and inhabitatnt of Spokane County, Washington, for the period of one year next preceeding the t$me when the said juror was drawn, called and examined; and that he the said petitioner, relator and defendant herein further alleges, that neither he nor his said attorneys had any knowledge whatever at the time of the said examination or at any time before the 18th day of November, A. D. 1897, that the said juror Isador Lipschuetz had ever at any time resided in the State of Idaho, but relied upon the truth of the answers of said juror that he the said juror had resided in Spokane Coounty for about eight years preceeding said time.

10- And the said George Webster the petitioner, relator and defendant herein further alleges, as his second assignment of error of fact for which a Writ of Error Coram Nobis should be issued here- in, that the said juror upon his said examination was asked the fol- lowing questions.

Q Do you know anything about the facts in this case? To which the said juror then and there answered Noair. Q Have you read anything about it in the paper? To which the juror answered I did. Q Did you read what purported to be the report of the shooting immediately after it occurred, in the paper? To which the said Juror answered, I read about it in the paper. Q From the reading of those reports, or from any other reason, did you form or express any opinion as to the guilt or innocence of the defendant? To which the juror answered, No sir. Q Have you any opinion as to his guilt or innocence? To which the juror answered, No sir.

And upon examination by Mr. Fenton of counsel for the said defendant, the said juror was asked to and he answered the folloeing questions as follows; Q Have you read anything about the case? A I have. Q When was that? A At the time the shooting occurred last spring. Q When was that? Q Sometime last sprng, when it look place. Q Have you talked about this case, State against Webster? A Nothing but comment on what I read. Q Have you talked with anyone about the case? A No sir. Q Now from what you have read about the case, and from what you have heard about it, have you formed any opinion as to the guilt or innocence of the defendant? A I never form an opinion on newspaper talk. Q Have you now the opinion as to the guilt or innocence of the defendant? A More whatever. Q Have you now such an opinion as require evidence to change that opinion? A No sir. Q Do you know anything that would prevent you from being a fair and impartial juror? N No sir. Q Do you know that words prevent you from being a fair and impartial juror? A Not to my knowledge.

Whereas in truth the said juror Isador Lips- chuetz although pretending at the tim of said extremeisnm not to know anything about the facts in the case and that he had formed no opinion as to the guilt or innocence of the said relator and pe- titioner upon said charge, had in fact previous to the commencement of said trial of the said relator upon said information, fully dis- cussed the facts in said case and had in fact previous to his being called as a juror in said case, formed and expressed an opinion that the said petitioner and relator was guilty of the offense charged in said nformation and in truth and in fact the said juror Isador Lips- chuetz upon his said examination as said juror, in order to remain upon said jury and in order to prevent the said defendaht from chal- lenging the said juror for cause on account of the expressed and im- plied bias, testified and swore falsely touching the length of time he the said juror had reided in Spokane County, and touching the fact as to whether or not he the said juror had formed or expressed an opinion as to the guilt of the said relator, and the said petition- er and relator herein further alleges; that neither he nor his said attorneys had any knowledge whatever of the prejudice and bias of the said juror Isador Lipschuetz until aft erthe judgment and sen- tence of the Court herein upon the verdict of the jury in said cause but he the said petitioner and relator relied upon the testimony of the said juror to the effect that he was a fair and impatial juror, and that he had not formed or expressed any opinion as to the guilt or innocence of the said relation and peitioner said relator alleges; that he was deceived and mislead by the fraud and false statements of the said Juror Isador Lipschuetz touching his qualifications to sit as a juror in said cause.

11- And the said petitioner, relator and defendant herein for a third assignment of error of fact for which a Writ of Error Coram Nobis should issue herein, that after the said cause, the State of Washington against George Webster, had been submitted to the jury for their deliberation and while the said jury was deliberating up- on their said verdict, he the said juror Isidor Lipschuetz was in posession of facts within his own knowledge, and facts that had not been testified to by any of the witnesses upon the trial of such cause that conviced him, the said juror Isidor Lipschuetz be- yound a reasonable doubt that the said petitioner, relator and defend- and was guilty of the crime charged in the said information, and that the said petitioner, relator and defendant herein should be hanged for said offense. And the same petitioner, relator and defendant herein alleges, that neither he nor his said attorneys jad any know- ledge whatever of the said statements made by the said Isidor Lips- chuetz to one of the jury until after he the said petitioner, relat- or and defendant herein had been sentenced by the above entitled Court.

11 1/2- And the said petitioner, relator and defendant above named further alleges; that at the time the said Isidor Lipschuetz voted Wallace Precinct No. 2 in the County of Shoshone in the State of Idaho on the 3rd day of November, A. D. 1896, the laws of the State required that the said Isidor Lipschuetz should at said time, be a resident of the said State for the period of six months, which he the said Isidor Lipschuetz then and there well knew. And the said petitioner, relator and defendant above named, further alleges, that the said Juror Isidor Lipschuetz on the 8th day of April, A. D. 1897, unlawfully registered as a voter in the City of Spokane, State of Washington, and on the same day made and subscribed to the following oath at the time of his registration.

I, Isidor Lipschuetz do solemly swear or affirm that I am a male person over twenty years eleven months and ten days of age, that I am a naturalized citizen of the United States; that I have been an actual permanent resident of the State of Washington for eleven months and ten days last past, of the County of Spokane for seventy days last past, and of the pre- cinct ten days last past, and that I have not lost my civil rights by reason of being convicted of an infamous crime.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 8th day of April, 1897.
L. F. Boyd, City Clerk and ex- officio Register.

To which said oath, the said Isidor Lipschuetz unlawfully and falsely swore that he had been a resident of the State of Washington for a period of 11 months and ten days prior to the date of making said oath, whereas in truth and in fact the said Isidor Lipschuetz in less than five months and a half previous to the making of said oath, had voted in Wallace Precinct No. 2 in Shoshone County in the State of Idaho, as he then and there knew in truth and in fact the petitioner, relator and defendant is informed and believes, and therefore alleges, that the said Isidor Lipschuetz is not now a cit- izen of the United States, and the said petitioner, relator and de- fendant above named further alleges, that the time the said Juror Isidor Lipschuetz was being examined touching his qualifications as a juror at the time that he answered upon said examination, that he had resided in the City of Spokane for the period of about eight years, well knew that no paerson was elligible or qualified to act or serve as a juror in the above entitled Court until he had been a continuous resident and inhabitant of Spokane County, Washington, for the period of one year next preceedings the time when he was drawn and called as a juror; and he the said juror Isidor Lipschuetz at the said time of his said examination as juror well knew that he was not qualified to act and serve as a juror in saidcause and well knowing said fact testified falsely in relation thereto in order to deceieve and mislead this petitioner, relator and defendant and his said attorneys.

12- And the said petitioner, relator and defendant herein further alleges, that the time for appeal in the said cause the State of Washington against George Webster, expires on the 15th day of Februrary, A. D. 1898, and that the said petitioner, relator and defendant herein is now under sentence of the above entitled Court to be hanged on the 4th day of February, A. D. 1898, and further al- leges that he the said petitioner, relator and defendant had no op- porunity whatever to present to, or bring to the attention of, this Honorable Court any of the errors in fact alleged herein upon the verdict of the jury in the said cause of the State of Washington against George Webster, and further alleges, that had this Honorable Court known of any of the errors of the fact alleged herein, prior to the rendering of the said judgment and sentence by the said Court that the judgement and sentence rendered herein would not have been made...

WHEREFORE? the petitioner and relator herein being the defend- ant in the said action in the case of the State of Washington against George Webster, prays that a Writ of Error Coram Nobis issue herein, and that upon the hearing of said Writ of Error, the said petitioner, relator and defendant above named, have the errors of facts assigned herein tried, and decided by a jury, to be impanelled by this Court and that if said jury shall find in favor of said petitioner, relat- or and defendant, that he have a judgment and decree of this Court recalling and revoking the judgment and sentence heretogore made and rendered by this Court, adjudging the said defendant guilty of mur- der in the first degree and sentencing him the said petitioner to be hanged on the 4th day oof February, A. D. 1898, and that pending the hearing and determinaton of this matter, the execution of the said sentence be stayed and arrested, and that the said petitioner and relator have such other and further relief as the Court shall deem just ti the end that speedy justice may be done him the said relator.
Del Cary Smith Fenton and O'Brien, Attorneys for peti- tioner, relator, and defendant.

I, George Webster being duly sworn say; that I am the pe- titioner and relator herein and the defendant in the case No. 771 en- titled the State of Washington, plaintiff, -vs- George Webster, de- fendant. That I ha ve read the foregoig petition for a Writ of Error Coram Nobis, know the contents thereof and the allegation therein are tru.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 3rd day of January, A. D. 1898
Del Cary Smith N O T A R Y P U B L I C for Washington, resid- ing at Spokane.

Barry N. Hillard being first duly sworn on oath deposes and says:- That he is now and has been since the second Monday in January, A. D. 1891, the duly elected qualified and acting Clerk of the District Court ad ex-officio Recorder, Auditor and Clerk of the Board of County Commissioners in and for Shoshone County in the State of Idaho; that as such Auditor and Clerk of the Board of County Commissioners he is the legal custodian of the Election Register of Wallave Pre- cinct No.2 of Qualified Electors for the General Election November 3rd, A. D. 1896, and of the Poll Book of said General Election held on Tuesday, November 3rd, 1896, in Wallace Pre- cinct No. 22, in Shoshone County, State of Idaho; that said books are now in his office and in his custody; that in said Election Register of Qualified Electors for said Wallace Pre- cinct No.2 in Shoshone County, State of Idaho, the following entry concerning one "Isador Lipschuetz", appears of record, to-wit:--

"Number 235, Isador Lipschuetz, Date of Registry, Oct 17th, 1896, Where born, Germand, Age 41, Description of Residence, Idaho Hotel, Certificate of Naturalization exhibit, yes or no, "No", remarks, "Sworn to them out in Philadelphia, 1876, and lost them in Idaho, in Summerfield Store, 1895." That in said Poll Book for said General Election held Tuesday, November 3rd, A. D. 1896, in Wallace No. 2 Precinct, Shoshone County, State of Idaho, the following entry concerning one "Isadore Lipschuetz" appears of record, to-wit:-
"Number and names of Elector voting, No. 2. "Isadore Lipschuetz".

Affiant futher says that the aforesaid Poll Book is duly attested by the Judges and Clerks of said General Election and was the official return of said General Election to the Board of Canvassers of said Election. And further affiant saith not.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this the 18th day of December, A. D. 1897.
Winfield Ervin, Nortary Public. Shoshone County, Idaho, residing at Murray.

I, Philip McNulty being duly sworn say; that I was one of the duly appointed, acting, and qualified judges in and for Cannon Pre- cinct at the City Election in the City of Spokane, in the State of Washington , on the 4th day of May , A. D. 1897, that I am acquianted with Isidor Lipschuetz who registered in said Precinct on the 8th day of April, A. D. 1897; that the said Isidor Lipschuetz is a bar- ber doing business on Main Street in the City of Spokane, Washington, of about the age of 41 years and the same person who served as juror in the cause of the State of Washington against George Webster, de- fendant above named. That said Isidor Lipschuetz voted at the said City Election on the 4th day of May , A. D. 1897, in Cannon Precinct, and that his name was put opposite the No. 64. That the said Isidor Lipschuetz is the same person who made and subscribed and af- fidavit and filed the same with the Clerk of the City of Spokane, to the effect that he was a naturalized citizen of the United States, and that he had been an actual permanent reisdent of the State of Washington, for 70 days prior to said time, and a resident of Can- non Precinct 10 days prior to said time.

And affidavit further deposes and says; that on the 3rd day of January , A. D. 1898, he saw the said Isidor Lipschuetz at his Barber- Shop on Main Avenue, in Spokane, Washington, and then and there had a conversation with the said Isidor Lipschuetz, and the said Isidor Lipschuetz resided then and there stated to affiant that he, tha said Isidor Lipschuetz resided in the town of Wallace, Idaho, and was in the Bar- ber business in the said twon of Wallace, on the 3rd day of November, 1896; that he the said Isidor Lipschuetz voted in Wallace Precinct on the 3rd day of November, A. D. 1896 at the Prseidential Election held in the said Precinct on said date, and that he the said Isidor Lipschuetz also voted in Cannon Precinct on the 4th day of May ,A.D. 1897, at the City Election of the City of Spokane held in said Pre- cinct on said date, and that he the said Isidoe Lipschuetz served as a juror in the above entitled case, No. 771, that State of Washington plaintiff, -vs- George Webster, defendant, in the above entitled Court, and that he, the said Isidor Lipschuetz, who served upon the said jury, was the same person who voted in in Wallace Precinct on the 3rd day of November, A.D. 1896, and the same person who voted in Cannon Precinct in the City of Spokane, on the 4th day of May, A. D. 1897.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 3rd day of Jan'y, A.D. 1999
W. M. Byers, Notary Public for Washington, residing at Spokane, Washington.

I, L. F. Boyd, being duly sworn say; that I am now and have been ever since the 21st day of May, A. D. 1896, the duly elected, qualified and acting Clerk of the City of Spokane, Washington. That as such Clerk I am the legal custodian of the Election Register of Cannon Precinct in the Third Ward in and for the said City, of the qualified electors for the City Election held in Spokane, Washington, on the 4th day of May , A. D. 1897, and of the Poll Book of the said City Election held on the 4th day of May , A.D. 1897, in the said Can- non Precinct in the Third Wards of said City. That said books are now in my office and in my custody. " Registration Book, City of Spokane, Cannon Precinct, Third Ward, Number Registered Votes 225, Registered Poll List, Cannon Pre- cinct, City of Spokane, Washington, for the year 1897, date of reg- istration April 8th, 1897, name, Isidor Lipschuetz, age 41 years, oc- cupation, Barber, Place of residence #1204 Fourth Avenue, Place of birth, Germany, Time of residence in State 7 years, in County 7 ears, in ward 7 months. Time and place of declaration of intention of naturalization, Philadelphia, Pa. Date of Intention of naturalization, A. D. 1876, Signature, Isador Lipschuetz."

That the said Poll Book for said City Election held on the 4th day of May, A.D.1897, in said City and Ptecinct, in the Third Ward in the City of Spokane, State of Washington, the following entry concern ing one Isidor Lipschuetz appears of Record, to-wit:-

"Poll Book of elelction held in Cannon Precinct, City of Spo- kane of Washinto n, on the 4th day of May, A. D. 1897at which time A. Traut was inspector, J. H. Bishop and P. McNulty was Judges and H. L. Cannon and J. A. Crowley were Clerks, or said election, the following named person vating there, No .64, name of voter, Isidor Lipschuetz."

Affiant further says that the aforesaid Poll Book is duly at- tested by the Inspector, Judges, and Clerks of said City Election, and was the official return of said City Election to the City Counsil in and for the City of Spokane, Washington, acting as a Board of Can- vassers at said election, and affiant further deposes and sayd that at the time the said Isidor Lipschuetz registered on the said 8th day of April, A.D.1897, he and made subscribed the following oath, to- wit:--

I, Isidor Lipschuetz do solemly swear or affirm that I am a male person over twenty years, eleven months ,and ten days of age, that I am a naturalized citizen of the United States, that I have been an actual permanent resident of the State of Washington for eleven months and ten days last past, of the County of Spokane for seventy days last past, and of the Precinct ten days last past, and that I have not lost my civil rights by reason of being convicted of an infamous crime.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 8th day of April, 1897.
L. F. Boyd, City Clerk and ex- officio-Register.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 3rd day of January, a. D.1898.
Del Cary Smith N O T A R Y P U B L I C for Washington, residing at Spokane, Washington.

IN AND FOR THE COUNTY OF SPOKANE.
In the Matter of the application of George Webster, for
A Writ of Error Coram Nobis

I, R. J. Frazier being duly sworn say; That I am one of the jurors who tried the above named petitioner, relator and defendant. That I am acquainted with Isidor Lipschuetz who was also one of the jurors who tried the said petitioner, relator and defendant above named. That I was present in the Court Room durinng the timw the said Isidor Lipschuetz was being examined, touching his qualifications to act and serve as a juror in said cause. And that in answer to the questions propounded to the said Isidor Lipschuetz as to his length of residence in Spokane County, he the said juror answered that he had resided in said City of Spokane for about eight years, and in answer to the following question; "Do you know anything that would prevent you from being a fair and impartial juror?" he the said juror Isidor Lipschuetz answered "Not to my knowledge." And in answe to the following question, "Have you no such an opinion as to require evidence to change that opinion?" the said juror answ ered, "No, sir." Whereas in truth and in fact the said Isidor Lips- chuetz while the jury were deliberating on the verdict of said cause, stated to this affiant that he the said Isidor Lipschuetz was in pos- session of facts within his own knowledge, and facts that have not been testified by any of the witnesses on trial of said cause that convinced him the said Isidor Lipschuetz beyond a reasonable doubt that the sad petitioner, relator and defendant above named was guilty of the crime of murder and that he should be hanged for such offense. And affiant further deposes and says, that the said juror Isidor Lipschuetz during the deliberation of the jury, became and was extremely bitter and malicious in his conduct toward said peti- tionerm relator and defendant above named, and told this affiant that he said Isidor Lipschuetz, had made up his mind that the said George Webster was guilty of said offense before any testimony in the cause had been offered, and repeatedly said to the affiant in the jury room "I would like to see Webster taken out of the jail right now and hung without any further trial or delay of any kind".
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 30th day of December, 1897.
Del Cary Smith N O T A R Y P U B L I C for Washington, residing at Spokane, Washington.
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON
IN AND FOR THE COUNTY OF SPOKANE.
In the Matter of the application of George Webster, for
A Writ of Error Coram Nobis

I, James E. Fenton, being duly sworn say that I am one of the attorneys for the above named petitioner, relator and defendant, George Webster. That on the 3rd day of November, A.D. 1896, the fol- lowing provision of the Constitution of the State of Idaho, was in force and effect touching the qualifications of the electors.

Section 2. Except as in this Article otherwise provided, every male citizen of the United States, twenty-one years old, who has actually resided in this State of Territory, for six months and in the County where he offers to vote, 30 days next preceeding the day of election, is registered as provided by law is a qualified elector; and until otherwise provided by the Leg- islature, who have the qualifications prescribed in this Ar- ticle, may continue to hold such school office and vote at such school elections, as provided by the laws of Idaho Territory."

That the said Constitution of the State of Idaho, which the said Sec. 2, of Art. 6 was a part, was adopted on the 6th day of August, A. D. 1899 and the same is now and has ever since said date been in full force and effect and has not been amended.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 3rd day of January, 1898.
Del Cary Smith N O T A R Y P U B L I C for Washington, residing at Spokane, Washington.

Subscribed and sworn to before me this 3rd day of January, 1898.
W. M. Byers N O T A R Y P U B L I C for Washington, residing at Spokane, Washington.
